Comment:
This is brand new for me -- I've never even prepared for it in my opening database.
I know that I need to play Nf3. I'm guessing that he's ready to capture on f3, and I can't imagine taking back gxf3.
But having pawns on f3 and f2 isn't a completely bad arrangement. They protect e3 and e4 from invasion, and it makes me want to play d4 to control e5, too.

Sometimes I think that the most valuable thing about extremely uncommon moves like Bg4 is it creates doubt in my mind about my opening. I'm thinking it's because I don't play and read chess so frequently that I have more natural confidence in what I'm doing.
But isn't that an ongoing trade-off? The beginners I teach are always extremely confident -- so confident that they move way too fast and tend to fall off the virtual cliff because of the simple things they overlook.

I'll be getting my knight out soon. I haven't decided whether to put him on a3 (then where would he go) or d2 heading to f3. I'm not ready to block my bishop yet. In the meantime, I know that I'll need to make this move, so I'll go ahead and do it and see what his plans are.

So I think his last move was just a mistake. I don't see any fantastic follow-up for him. Now, I just need to trade off some more pieces and win in the ending. I look at this position and can confidently say that no one's going to checkmate in the middle game -- the winner will be the person that gets another queen. That's what I'm working towards.
